bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Miguel Galindo to the Secretary General in Charge of the Department of Public Health, Mexico, September 6, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302020]

div1.p: Galindo writes about his examination of the body of the man suspected of dying from yellow fever in Colima, Mexico. He states that he does not believe that yellow fever was the cause of death and asks that the results of an examination of a liver specimen be communicated to him as Sanitary Delegate for the region.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Miguel Galindo to the Secretary General in Charge of the Department of Public Health, Mexico, September 6, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302020]
div1.opener:
Translated from the Spanish
9-6-23
HRM
TO THE SECRETARY GENERAL IN CHARGE OF THE DEPARTMENT OF
PUBLIC HEALTH, MEXICO, D.F.
div1.p:
I have the honor to inform you on the suspected case of yellow
fever which I reported in my telegram on the 21st of this month:

Proceeding from Manzanillo where he had left on the 13th,
Luis B. Corona arrived in this city suffering from no disease; but later
he felt pains in the abdomen and legs, and soon thereafter fever develop-
ed. The fever rose on each third day. On the sixth day he was given a
saline purgative which caused abundant yellowish fetid and mucous evacua-
tions, containing small traces of blood. This alarmed his family and it
was decided to call for a doctor - Dr. Jośe Ma. Herrera.

Dr. Herrera confirmed the above mentioned characteristics of the
evacuations; pulse 130, temperature 38 C., abdomen soft to palpation and
tympanic to percussion; hypertrophy of the liver and spleen, perfect men-
tality; damp tongue having a dirty and uniform color; gums showed no
changes. The patient did not complain of any disturbances other than those
caused by the frequent evacuations. Arsenas quinine was prescribed.

After the administration of this drug, the evacuations became
markedly hemorrhagic. On the 20th, Dr. Ciro Hurtado was summoned to see
the patient. Dr. Hurtado found the patient with very weak pulse and in
a very unrestful state, moving from side to side, with high temperature,
and almost in a state of agony. He died three hours after Dr. Hurtado
had seen him. The latter was informed that after Corona's death, the
cadaver bled from the nose, and the body was markedly yellowish in color.
The death certificate was issued as suspected yellow fever.

The undersigned was informed of this matter by Mr. Richardson.
We immediately went to the patient's home; we took note of pertinent data.
We were told that the cadaver had been taken to the cemetery. We went
- 2 -
there arriving just as he was being buried.

I do not think that the appearance of the cadaver was that of
yellow fever; Mr. Richardson agreed with me on this point. The hands
had the usual yellowish color seen in cadavers; the face was swollen;
there was ecchymosis of the eyelids, and abundant nasal hemorrhages. The
autopsy showed profuse intestinal hemorrhages, fetid gases, pale liver,
the cross section of which was hard and icteric. A fragment was collected
which Mr. Richardson sent to your Department for study.

The undersigned will appreciate it very much and begs that the
result of the examination of the specimen be communicated to him for his
own knowledge and perfection in the fulfillment of his duty as a Sanitary
Delegate.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Miguel Galindo (Stamp) Sanitary Delegate.
Colima, August 23, 1923.
